A tour of Europe must include a visit to its many cathedrals as they often encompass the history of the city and the region. A magnificent example!
Amazing masterpiece of gothic architecture in the heart of the old city. Definitely recommend seeing
Stunningly beautiful church with simple architecture. Magnificent stained glassed windows and plenty of seating for the service. Well worth a visit.
Beautiful site. Best part is climbing the steward up to the top. Very adventurous and charming. The view of the city is breathtaking.

I was out in a business trip for the weekend, and had some free time on Sunday and I notice this beautiful church near the Christmas market, I looked up to see people walking outside at the very top near the steeple, and decided to go in. It cost 5 Chf to go to the roof. It was

This place was just amazing to visit. The archetecture was astonishing, and the history of the place inspiring. The fact that Emperor Heinrich and his wife Kunigunde were the patrons who established the church just made it even cooler.

This is one of those classic European cathedral type churches that are always nice to visit. And it us free!! Great stonework, lovely views to the back from the alter and 14th century tombs plus 23th century frescoes!!

We spent a lovely morning doing our own self-tour of Basel Munster. High on a hill you have a commanding view of the city and the Rhine. Its a good introduction to Basel and its history.
Behind the church is a spectacular view of the city across the Rhine river. Church is now a Protestant one, no longer Catholic. In December there is a Christmas Market by the church.
A bit of a climb, but well worth the effort. Beyond the historic value of this church, the view from the top is spectacular!

Beautiful cathedral with gothic style and design. Amazing view over the whole town and region from the towers.

Definitely worth exploring even in the summer - lots of infesting buildings such as the Rathaus (Town Hall). Beautiful views of the Rhine. Comes alive with the Christmas markets - well organised and so pretty with all the trees lit up !
Xmas market outside makes for a great atmosphere. Lovely walk above the Rhine to get to it from the bridge via the Rathaus.
Amazing architecture & stunning views. Don't miss the short walk to this beautiful church. There was a winter festival happening while we were there, and we went back several times.
It looks nice from the outside.. from inside its not that big.. the entrance was free.. they had a really nice christmas tree outside

I love the roof of the church. The different colors are just amazing. We didn't get to go inside so I can't say much more.
Walked up here as part of my solo exploration of Basel. Was lucky enough to come just as the Christmas Market had opened. Especially good were the views up and down the Rhine - what a great spot.
Whilst in Basel we visited the beautiful Basel Cathedral and were glad we did Terrific architecture and some stunning views Sadly we didn’t have enough time to climb the tower Worth a visit

Worth popping in if you are in the area. I would class it as pleasant but not exceptional - some nice stained glass windows. Great scenic views down to the river. When we were there, the immediate vicinity was not enhanced by a temporary fair.

It is nice historical place to visit with lots of history. As well the terrace behind the Munster is a must, as you have a great view of Basel from here. Take the small ferry going to the other side of the river which is just under the terrace
I recommend to go on the top of the Münster to see Basel in a better way. Stairs are steep ans narrow and maybe not confortable for old people.

Very nice view of the river.walking around that place is very nice!The area has some restaurants and coffees but make sure for the working hours
I found this munster just amazing, with it's gothic atmosphere and lovely windows situated in a quiet area of Basel. A must visit.
well, a typical European Cathedral. its swiss, so very clean and organised. has nice lawns around it. colourful interior and nice exterior. u can walk down here easily and enjoy the sight.
Very nice cathedral. Slightly ruined by the gypsy fun fair next door. Nice views of the river. The only thing to do in Basel if you don’t like art and basel aren’t playing
Well worth a visit to this cathedral. Stunning acoustics and beautiful internally and one of the nicest buildings in Basel.
The Cathedral is an appealing part of the city skyline but when we visited it was being set up as s venue for an art display so we didn’t stay long.

We first approached the Minster from the side and were attracted to the cloisers by a musician busking. This was a lovely area, with nice views over the river and a quiet space to wander around. We then proceeded to the main church with a delightful aspect overlooking the main

We made a short visit on a walking tour and found the burial place of Erasmus here and a portrait of him by Holbein the younger. Very interesting building with two towers that can be climbed for a fee of 5 francs according to our guide. The inside has a plate with a dragon on

went around Basel on a Sunda morning and I found myself alone walking down the streets! just followed the roads and found myself in this beautiful cathedral :) the doors and walls were amazing! i didnt know that you can go inside and climb up the towers, so i failed to do that

We visited on Easter weekend and the Easter decorations in the old section surrounding Basel Munster were beautiful. The wisteria was in bloom and was really gorgeous. Below Basel Munster is the people ferry. We enjoyed a ride across after going the church at Clara platz.
This church is beautiful and so interesting. make sure you take a look downstairs! medieval, not gothic.
The munster is beautiful from to see, that’s for sure, but the real highlight is the possibility to climb all the way up to the end of the castle. Don’t miss it.
This is a must see in Basel and the plaza out back is not to be missed. I loved the setting in the ancient yet lived in square.
Vera interesting and charming city with quiet places and lovely streets. Kind people and very good brasseries
Make sure you go right to the top for an amazing/epic view over Basel you will also get a 360 degree view
Beautiful spot. The church offers a quiet prayer time Monday to Friday during lunch. The church is reformed Swiss church. Much planer than usually in Europe.

We enjoyed visiting this church. The amazing thing is they let you climb up the towers. We did it and the views were amazing. Not for anyone who has fear of heights! The inside of the church is very beautiful.
Begun in the 12th century, the Basel Munster is situated on a bluff overlooking the Rhine River. We enjoyed its exterior and interior architecture and views of the river from its grounds.
Not the biggest or grandest Cathedral we're visited but can't be missed! Interesting Gothic structure
Set in a lovely area of town. Easy to walk to. Stunning inside and out from every angle and take a walk across the river to get a different view.
stunning, with view over the river . Lovely place to have lunch and reflect the world as it goes by. Watch out for school trips. Can be noisy and chaotic
Stunning architecture and amazing views of the Rhine into Germany. Stained glass windows are breathtakingly beautiful. Definitely worth a visit.
Try to go there during one of the organ recitals. Also try to visit the crypt; we could not, and try to visit a tower- we could not.
This is one of the most important sites in Basel. It is easy to spot and hugs the river. Don't miss the garden area alongside the sanctuary. Some very fine modern sculptures in that area.

Beautiful old Church, most popular probably for the magnificent views you get from the rear courtyard. Lovely stonework inside, some amazingly old inscripted crypts, gorgeous stained glass windows, still in use today.
When in the Basel area, a visit to this town square containing this church is recommended. Very neat outside decor.
The place to go to view Klein Basel from above. It is also very historic and an interesting place to visit
The Basel Munster is the city cathedral. Built of red sandstone, it is a marvel that must be seen to be appreciated. Admission is free.
Really impressive church with a nice atmosphere inside. You have a great view from the two towers towards Kleinbasel and over the Rhine.
The cathedral is okay but it's definitely worth paying 5CHF to go up the tower. The views are great and it's a long way up! The tower closes at 4pm

Only visited to escape the rain and get directions for the Hop on Hop off bus. (After visiting various cities in Europe you no longer 'wonder' at the next church/cathedral /minster. Staff were accommodating.

From outside the church you can see a very interesting architecture that dates back to some hundreds of years. The church is well preserved and in December I even see reworks being done to make sure it keeps its architecture preserved. A must visit in Basel

A lovely cathedral situated in Basel's Munsterplatz. A beautiful structure from the out side and equally lovely from the inside. We spent a good time in the cathedral and the outside walking around and admiring the huge structure. The Platz is full of beautiful old trees that

I always enjoy taking my friends to the Münster in Basel, because it is such a beautiful historical monument, shows the evolution of the architectural style in Basel especially Gothic and Baroque. You have access to a tower from where you have a view onto all of Basel. But you

I loved the VIEW! The entrance to the Church is free, but to go upstairs - long way - be ready- will cost you 5 swiss franks. I would recommend to spend this money and take the opportunity to see he whole city of Basel. As well you could have a look at the very old part of the

This definitely is a must visit in Basel. Whilst the cathedral is free, it is 5 CHF to climb to the top of the spires. However, you must be in a pair, so lone travellers may have to partner up. As the walkways, stairways and balconies at the top are incredibly narrow, this isn't
Basel Munster is a beautiful place to visit when in Basel, offering a nice view of the Rhine and Klein Basel. To get there, you walk through the old town which is such a pleasure.
Spent an hour sitting at the tops with my kids. Has some cool black food sculptures that were pretty interesting. Not your usual Munster but still nice to walk through (to get to the views).
Interesting to see but it is a bit underwhelming if you've seen a lot of impressive European churches. Come here for the history and not necessarily for a visual feast.

The history of this place and the condition it's in are both impressive. If you want, head to the top and have a view of the city. Be sure to look at the gargoyle's and the various adornments - quite interesting. In other words, always look up :) you'll always miss something

The Münster is a dominating feature on the landscape, and despite its relatively bland interior, features a couple of exquisite contemporary marble sculptures. For CHF5, you can climb up to the spires to enjoy an awe-inspiring view over Basel and presumably contribute to the
Nice cathedral & the courtyard has great views over the Rhine, good central location in the old town - very nice...

Just as we went upstream the course of river Rhine from the site of Rathaus,that is, to the southeast, before long we came in the Platz, on which is situated very beautiful Munster Church. It is considered together with the Mittlere Brucke(The Middle Bridge), as the most famous

If you're visiting Basel then you have to visit the Munster. There are great views of Basel and the river, plus it's an amazing building with incredible stone work and fantastic interior. If you have time, it's definitely worth going up the tower itself - it does cost a few
Great architecture and the most scenic river and city views. The history in the church is truly amazing. If your timing is right try to catch an organ recital.
A standard church visit, very nice architecture but only worth a few minutes of visiting time. Easily accessible.
We were too late to see inside. Very disappointed but took some pics of the beautiful outside. The building is quite large so go around to all sides.
We enjoyed visiting the cathedral. Really pretty fassade, looking really good. It's definitely worth visiting

This is up a little slope and from its grounds you get a slightly elevated view of the area. It is a peaceful break from, the shops and cafes. In my opinion it is not as stunning as St Stephen's in Vienna, the Cathedral of our Lady in Antwerp or Sagrada Familai in Barcelona, but

The Münster is kind of the icon of the city, always present on the Rhine skyline. If you have a chance go up one of the towers to get a scenic view of the so called Rhine-knee, the meandering part of the Rhine.

Church has an interesting history and it's worth taking time to wander around the grounds. Initially we went inside and took in the stain glass windows, the altar and marveled at the structure. At the last minute,we walked over to the side into a courtyard and then behind the

This beautifully kept architectural statement is so beautiful and the artwork on the buildings and walls is wonderful to see. You can spend a few minutes or a longer time here, but not to be missed if you are in the area. Awesome spot to see, whether you are a local or a

This red rock church is beautiful. The facade is awesome. Note the man courting the girl and then walk to see his snakes behind. The doorways have whisper ways so one can talk to another without appearing to do so. The interior is regal.

Foremost among churches in Basel is this cathedral, a wonderful example of gothic architecture. Loved the colorful roof tiles. Attended church services there since I was there on a Sunday morning, although it was conducted in German. The organ music was particularly wonderful.

we went to the old city for a walk and found a beautiful experience. the architecture and the places along the walk for a drink. Crossing the Rhine in the current driven boat/Ferry was a nice experience and then walking on the river front watching the locals swim the river made

We have been to a lot church and cathedral. It is a nice place but the nicest part was to climb to the top. For €5 each, you can climb to the top. The staircase is extremely narrow but it has a rope by the wall so you can use it to assist the climb. It reminded us of climbing to

Nice walk up to the Munster. They did some renovation, so the entrance was not easy to find. Could climb up the two towers and enjoy the great view over Basel and the river Rhine. After walked down the steps to the river and crossed with a small ferry to the other side.

It is a monumental piece of architecture on a hill. Do not miss Kreuzgang! I assume there are tombs of some important people beneath the granite floor. Both views - from the hill, where the Munster is located and from the other side of Rhine on the Munster are cool!

The Munster, on the river banks, is indeed a stunning example of Goth architecture, with its wall carvings, windows, domes and stained glass! You can walk through the columned hallways and up to some levels as well. Enjoy the view from the courtyard and square looking out to the
Stroll around the old city. Admire the cathedral, its inner architecture and its exterior outline, the reddish colour of the stone.

This is a large, attractive cathedral with a relatively bare interior (much was stripped away when changed from Catholic to Protestant). You can still see some of the painted walls and the artwork is gorgeous. Climbing the towers is possible and gives and incredible view. Note

Any visit to Basel must include a trip to the Munster. It's a very special place. If you're fit enough do the trip up the towers - heads for heights are needed though. Views are stunning and worth the strain. Lovely view of the city from behind the Munster at ground level

This square has amazing energy, it's really peaceful and calming. The church is beautiful and you can visit inside, outside and some open galleries. All really really nice. There's a surprise view over the river if you walk to the gardens out back. Restaurant and transportation
Wow - we stumbled in while a guy was lighting up the pipes. The sound was fantastic - try to find out when they play and drop in - no charge.

Very nice church that is also the resting place for Erasmus. A pity that all the highlights are not in english so as a tourist, I can only appreciate the art and the structure without knowing the meaning behind it. Recommended to do some homework before going.
We attended the a church service at the Basel Munster. The organ music and choir were excellent and our visit was very memorable.

Basel is definitely worth a visit with a nice city centre where authentic old buildings and churches mix with modern fashion shops. Two tips: Visit the bar rouge for a magnificent view on the town and surroundins. Second one; buy an unique swim bag and take a swim in the river

Walking up the hill on narrow cobble stone streets until you reach the open plaza before the church gives you a magnificent view of this beautiful church built in 1200's.The cloister to the right of the entrance shelters the crypts of bishops and rulers of the the past

This place has nice memories associated with it. I used to come here with family. I particularly like coming here on work days when it is all very quiet. Another nice thing to do here is to climb up the tower and get a good view around. It can be done when there is someone to go
When we visited this church, we were not able to see all of it as some part was under restoration. However, unique thing about this church is it's roof with colorful tiles.

My wife and I visited the church today and had a great view of the whole city from the church tower. Highly recommended. It costs 5 Swiss Franc per person. You cannot go up alone and has to be accompanied by someone. Good rule to prevent the sad ones doing stupid things.
The best part is climbing it up via its small stairs and dark passages! Minimum of two people everytime, 1-2 euros, do ti!

It was pure serendipity that led us to the Munster at about 15:30 on Saturday. We entered to enjoy the beauty of the church, and stayed to enjoy both the organist practicing (and playing a Bach toccata), as well as a practice of the Boys' Choir, which was outstanding. We

Nice view of the river and city and beautiful church! Was great to enjoy on a summer's day! The inner yard of the church is really pleasant and the view to the river is the best in town. Usually there are many people visiting or taking breaks (like scholars), but during working
Beatiful and easy location . The construction is amazing and take only half a hour to visit . it is one of the nice spots in that so lovely city .

The Munster is a beautiful cathedral, outside and inside. In other cathedrals you are always looking up at the stained glass windows but this Munster has a mezzanine floor that puts you at the same level as some of the windows. It was a great opportunity to examine the
I reviewed the entire cathedral and grounds in another review of Muensterplatz. The entire area is the experience, but the cathedral gives a wonderful respite among the ancient things.
While this looks great from the outside as I tried to enter there was a sign to say sightseeing not welcome. So that was that.

The cathedral and a climb up its tower is a must do in Basel. From its top, it offers a panoramic view of Rhine and Basel. On a clear day, it is a photographer's delight. A deep shot of the street below from the top with f/22 can give the viewer a sense of its height. Tickets

You cannot go to Basel and not go here! The building is beautiful and the inside doesn't disappoint. You must pay the extra 5 francs to go up to the top of the tower! The views are amazing! You could spend a good hour, hour 1/2 there touring the whole place.

Not for the faint-hearted or people who don't like close spaces, the climb up to the towers is via extremely narrow spiral staircases. Once you get to the top, however, the views are spectacular: you can see the Vosges in France and the Black Forest in Germany.
Awestruck by size of ancient craftsmanship. There is some renovation but it is a must see in Basel. View the North side and walk around to the Rhine.
Went here. Very nice overlooks river. Photos permitted. No fees. Bathroom across street. Saw people up higher. Don't know how to get up there.

This is not the most outstanding gothic cathedral of the region but the exceptionally beautiful surroundings with a view on the river Rhine make it a very attractive place to visit. The surrounding old quarter of Basel is very beautiful too.

We visited the cathedral incidentally at the end of a concert. Unfortunately we did not enjoy but 5 minutes of the concert. There is a schedule besides one of the doors of the cathedral so take a look, maybe something interests you. Other than that, this is a typical gothic
This minster has beautiful architecture and is in quiet area! I would definitely recommend going to visit this!

A fine example of a cathedral the Munster has an unparalleled view of the Rhine from the plaza in the rear. The adjoining cloister to the right is worth a visit and a climb up the tower gives way to a birds-eye 360 degree view of the entire city. Not for those with a fear of
We visited this cathedral as part of a walking tour. The guide pointed out some interesting historical facts which definitely added to the visit.

The red sandstone sets this one apart from other castles for me. Beginning in 1019 and continuing for ~500 years, the land where this cathedral is built has been used since the Celtic eras, destroyed and rebuilt several times. Very striking and the central part of Basel. We were
Beautiful cathedral, wonderful architecture and coloured roof tile. Peaceful and worth a visit. One of the top attractions at Basel.

There on Sunday and apparently not open during the afternoon. So all the comments about the peaceful interior were for naught. Lots of people looking to get in so I did not get the wrong door. Great from the outside. Note Jewish star on side window.

This cathedral is beautiful and impressive. It is in the center of the old town and worth a look. The setting on the main square is the perfect setting and the buildings around it only make it more impressive.

Quite impressive when you walk up from the Munsterberg. Apart from the main gate, the noticeable elements are a St Vincent bas-relief dated 1095 AD near Erasmus epitaph (left side inside) and the Sint-Gallen gate (outside), when walking left from the main gate, followed by the
If you can plan your trip to attend a service or concert the acoustics are phenomenal. On a quaint quiet square.

It's a very pretty town. The cathedral is fantastic. The color of the church is really impressive. But not only, also around it. It is on a a very pretty square. After visiting the cathedral, you must try the boat to cross the river which is very interesting and also a must.
The Munster itself is situated on the hilltop overseeing the Rhine river. A gorgeous place to visit and to walk around

It's a fabulous experience just to stand outside and take it in - and wander around the square in the spacious setting on the Rhine river. Munster is really what the wonderful city of Basel is all about. History in a modern setting with resonance of centuries.

An attractive gothic church. Impressive inside with nice cloisters. Ask for the archaeology key at the entrance visitor desk though, and you get to see the remaining parts of the earlier carolingian church with some pre-Roman and late Roman remains.
There is some obvious competitiveness among the cities and villages to have beautiful churches, and this one does not even vaguely disappoint. Beautiful, elegant, with very detailed history

This place is amazing from the red stone exterior to the beautiful stained glass windows on the inside. This is one of the most beautiful churches I've been to in Europe and the opportunity to climb the tower(s) is the highlight! Some things to keep in mind: 1) the climb in the

We appreciated the history and the architecture of this beautiful cathedral. The cloisters lead out to a quiet, peaceful area with great views of the river an the city. We were told that the platz in front of the church, while very quiet on the spring weekday we were there, is
The absolute best view of the Rhine and Basel! Incredible ! Stunning ! If there is one thing you must see is the view from this spot! Does not matter what the weather is ....... the view is great!
The cathedral has some impressive stained glass. You have to exit the cathedral to get to the cloister that overlooks the Rhine and one of the antique drift ferries that crosses it.

We visited this on a city tour of Basel with Viking River Cruise. Unique church with a mixture of Gothic and Romanesque features. Constructed of red sandstone that is abundant in the area. No cost to enter. If you are in the Basel area, it would be a good place to visit

By far the highlight of Basel. In truth there is not a huge amount to see in the city but this Münster and the surrounding square are lovely. Well worth going up the tower for the lovely views. Cost €18 for 3 adults and one student. Overall, Basel is not worth much more than

Like most tall churches in Switzerland, the Basle Münster is worth visiting even if it is just for the view you'll enjoy from the top of its bell tower. To get to see it you'll have to climb up a rather marvellously dark and precarious ancient staircase, which is not to be
This a a must see in Basel. Not only the church is fantastic, at thr Pfalz you will enjoy fantastic views to,Basel
Great Olde Town and square, church, well maintained, close to the Rhine, within 10 minutes of Hotel D and the tram.
Its so high that you can see the whole city. Very nice views and highly recommended to go on top. You can view the beautiful lake which is on the back of the munster. A must see.

Amazing place. At our visit they held an art exibition inside a silent yard next to the church itself. Behind is an observation area with amazing view over city and Rhine. You can see a small model of Münster there as well. You can buy drinks at one if the historic

Every European town has their fantastic scenic gothic cathedral and munster is Basels. This is well worth checking out as the building itself is a scene to behold in its beauty, particularly when you marbel that it was built hundreds of years ago long before any modern equipmwnt

Basel is a quaint, lively, colourful city. Munster is a beautiful church building with huge towers seen from a far distance, gleaming in sunshine with its beauty. 5 Euros entry fee to go up the tower was absolutely worth every penny spent. Narrow stairs in this quaint building

In terms of European cathedrals, it is neither the largest, most ornate nor is it truly grand. But it left an impression on me on a hot March, spring day. Inside it was truly serene, in stark contrast to the hordes of tourists gaggling outside. Unlike Protestant cathedrals that

This Cathedral at this Munster can be viewed across the river while traveling in the tram and is very inviting. The whole area in very historic and peaceful with a gorgeous surrounding. Spent close to an hour walking around the place and visiting the cathedral.
Great historic architecture in the heart of Basel. Overlooking the river and the ferry. Also the Münsterplatz is great also.
quick one hour in the evening. loved the intricate with and the architecture. loved the view of the city and the river from the balcony. too pricey to climb up to the top so skipped it.
Lovely Cathedral, with lovely views on the outside. Especially the Rheinfahre. On a clear day you could see both borders Germany on one side and France on the other.
You could see it from all over Basel. It was beautiful. Unfortunately it was closed when I went so I couldn't see the inside.

I was very impressed with the building and the surrounding area. It it well worth to climb up to the top to see a fantastic view (there are few viewing terraces on different levels). Inside the cathedral there is a grave of Erasmus of Rotterdam.

I love this area of Basel! The Munster is set near the water and has great views. The building itself is lovely and well worth a visit. There is a large square that is great to walk around in during warm weather and in the autumn is filled with rides for Herbstmesse. Well worth

Loose yourself in watching the details of this masterpiece of early craftsmanship. Climb the tower as well to gain a wonderful view over Basel. Have a rest on the terrace and watch the Rhine flow by...

Interesting sandstone building with twin towers set in a large picturesque square. The Munster has great stained glass windows and some very nice carvings. It’s a great place (both inside and out) for photography.

This church is made of red sandstone, and has some interesting carvings at the back, especially the 2 elephants. The 2 portals have nice sculptures, and are very well worth seeing. You will see more details with a zoom or binocular. The main portals has large statues. Inside the
Currently undergoing some renovation work but definitely worth a visit. The views are brilliant across the river Rhine and the streets around this area are well worth seeing too.
Set in a beautiful square, this cathedral is well worth a visit. Lots to see including the tomb of Erasmus. Would love to come back again when they have the Xmas market in the square.

I'm not a fan of churches but we were impressed with the outside decoration of the Munster so ventured in. A very impressive place with the most stunning, vibrant and detailed stained glass I have ever seen. Well worth a visit and it's free.

Great to visit especially for the view from one of the towers (5,- p.p.) although the climb up can be a bit challenging (spiral staircase and wooden stairs). Be careful: you will walk near the bells so esp. at the hour could be very noisy. The church itself is nice, although
Climbing the tower at this lovely church is fun and provides excellent views of the city. It's five francs for access to the tower and well worth it!

It was a walk with a friend from Portugal from Kunstmuseum to Münsterplatz and then Pfalz. This walk is definitely something that all visitors of Basel should do. From Pfalz you get the best overview over the river and the city.
A real experience looking around at the stain glass windows, great view from the top of the tower, free to walk around and sit for a while, very relaxing and can take pictures too.
Beautiful area awesome to visit, the most impressive is how huge all of the doorways are. Inside it is not huge but it is beautiful and ornate.
What a beautiful old church right on the banks of the Rhine. Could not have found a better spot to start exploring the old town.
In the middle of Basel, with a special terrace overlooking Rhine with special views. An impressive Gothic cathedral and a charnful square.

The church itself is lovely. It has different tombs in it. The stained glass windows are beautiful.and well worth a visit. We did go up to the tower and got as far as this gigantic bell. One needs to be fit and thin to get to the top as the stairs are very narrow! When we got to

Amazing cathedral in the heart of Basel. The highlight is being able to go up the two towers. Get ready for lots of spiral stairs, but it is more than worth it! It's incredible to see the interior of the bell mechanism, as well as the beams and construction of the towers. You

Basel Munster is an active worshipping community, encompassing the usual challenges of an ancient building in a postmodern secular era. There was much to love about this building, its location, and its layout. But somehow the visit left me somewhat unsatisfied. It's hard to put
Great place, super to hang out above the Rhine in the park behind the church. Very nice architecture and a peaceful place.

The Basler Münster is placed in the center of town. A beautiful experience is awaiting you, bringing you back in time. A great plus is the view at the back of the Basler Münster on the river Rhein and the town.

The munster is really nice and it is not only for those who likes "churches". There you will find art, nice statues, nice view of the river and more. It really worth it. And as it is close to everything so you can easily walk around.
Fantastic inside and out. It was very busy and a service was about o begin but the staff were very friendly and accommodating.
Münster cathedral, the best: impressive view of the river and the city, St. Gallen entrance, Erasmus sepulchre,, statues.
A must see place if you are visiting Basel. Look at the roof and spend some time during xmas as they decorate it in and out and around it!
We climbed up the bell tower, you get fantastic views from the various levels, which were well worth the effort. The spiral staircase is quite steep and narrow.

We started our amazing voyage up the Rhine in Basel and had a guided tour of the city. The highlight of the tour was viewing this lovely cathedral. The architecture of this red sandstone cathedral is a sight to see and quite picturesque. The cathedral was originally Catholic but

It was worth the payment and going up the narrow stairs. The top area can be a little frightening to people who are scared of heights but it is not dangerous. Some areas need some patience because only one person can walk through some narrow and small stairs so people wait to go

Basel is picture perfect. All of the old town buildings are expertly restored and beautifully maintained. A mammoth task. This is no exception. The stained glass is breathtaking. The architecture stunning. The tombs are incredible especially, for global scholars, Erasmus's

A must see on your visit to Basel. Lovely to walk through and the view of the Rhine from the back of the Cathedral should not be missed. There is a large open square at the front, very picturesque and just lovely to spend time and explore.

The cathedral itself is lovely, but the wide open space next to it is my favorite part of Basel. The buildings surrounding the square {Munsterplatz} are uniformally delightful and you have access to some of the best views over the Rhine. Throughout the year the square plays host
If you are wandering around Basel this is one place to visit. Go out back and check out the view of the river. As far as cathedrals go not overly impressive.

I was in Basel for a few days, and the city's landmark must be this Cathedral. This former Episcopal Church was built between the 12th & the 15th century in romanesque & gothic style. It is open to visitors, & the main part of the cathedral is free to wander about in. There is

A must see. Impressive, imposing structure with a commanding view of the river. I thought it quite interesting and we visited on an awful cold and rainy day! Can't imagine how lovely it must be in the better months!
Really free nice to visit church and spectacular view from the tower! ( entrace free just for the tower) If you like to climb up the towers, well this is an experience!
The only downside is that it is not open at any time, so be mindful of the opening times. Also as with any lookout point, better weather makes it more enjoyable. Otherwise must see in Basel.

I visited the cathedral on the occasion of the Christmas market, I was excited, it's a beautiful building, inside and outside, spiritual place, only regret that I did not succeed to climb the observation tower of the cathedral.
cathedral was simple and magnificent at the same time. The chairs inside were all hand carved but there was no figurines as you would find in others in this style. Well kept after and beautiful.
A beautiful ancient cathedral. I love all of the stained glass windows and the amazing architecture. I'm in awe as to how they constructed such a building so long ago. Worth a view.
This building is worth a visit, the inside is not a big as it looks from far away, but beautiful inside, so worth a visit. There are some guidebooks for sale inside if you wish for more informstion.

The building is nice and beautiful. Unfortunately, we couldnt go in as the church was closed on a xmas eve day. Nonetheless, behind the church is a view of basel's river and we could see the river boat and buildings opposite the river.

The Basel Cathedral is stunning with its details and red bricks. We had the fortune of passing it in the evening where it was covered in light and cornered with the Christmas market. The cathedral fit well into the surrounds and it is well worth to walk around in the
Lovely Cathedral in Basel city, with lovely architecture. Added bonus that the Christmas markets were right next to it. Didn't have time to go in - but lovely all the same.

Popped in..church itself is really pretty. Decided to head up the tower. Paid 5chf per adult (discounts available for students) It's a long way up and very claustrophobic but great view of Rhine.. would recommend 😀

A beautiful cathedral that lies high up looking down on the river Rhine. Built around 800 a.Chr. Originally there were 5 Towers, after the Major Earthquake of 1356 However, only 2 were re-built. Heigth of Towers 65 + 62 m.
Beautiful cathedral with a great view of the river and city. Nice inner courtyard with great character.
It was interesting architecture both inside and outside (rooftile has unique pattern). I think to climb the tower you need to buy ticket

The Munster at Christmas has a Christmas market outside and the ferry across the river just below. The outside is stunning but at Christmas we were disappointed to see very little in the way of nativity decoration or celebration.

If you are into history this is a good place to go. It gives you a better understanding of what formed the modern Basel. The views of the Rhine from the courtyard are breathtaking but pay the 2 Euros and climb to the top of the south spire. You will not be disappointed.

I visited the place twice: in the evening to enjoy the view and the lights from the terrace overlooking the river and in the morning to visit the monument. I liked the exterior best, the inside is quite simple but well kept

During a short visit to Basel we visited the Christmas market in the old town. Although somewhat cold weather it was a nice experience and some drops of the local christmas brew was making the evening very good!

Basel Munster is at the heart of Munsterplatz also home of the smaller Basel Christmas market. The church building has some great architecture with a life size knight defeating a dragon. The interior is just as impressive. Basel Munster is located around. 7 min stroll from the

Nice Munster, small but interesting. Free. For 1 Swiss Franc you can climb the tower.....go for it.....It is brilliant. More from the Alice in Wonderland-like stairs getting more narrow and tight the further up you go. There is a very, very narrow walkway around tower about

Stepped in for a visit. They had an exhibit of rare books. Wish I could read Swiss but hey. Only detraction was a harvest fair just outside with a lot of noise from the rides so we didn't get the peaceful experience others encountered. Still worth a visit. Great vistas of the

Overlooking the River Rhine, this stunning piece of architecture is a must see when visiting Basel. We were in Basel for the Christmas Markets one of which is in the adjacent square and made for some great selfie backdrops. My only regret was not getting to spend more time

The lofty interior provides a wonderful contrast to the bustle, light and crowds of the Christmas market alongside. It seems very austere but the red sandstone and warm temperature make for a calming atmosphere and make a welcome break from the low outside temperature.

We enjoyed two different tours of the Munster, discovering different things each time! I expecially loved the garden courtyard surrounded by archways, and also all the family crests on the wall. If you know a little latin you can try to decode them, and unlock further histories

We were fortunate to visit while an exhibit of the humanist Erasmus and his translations of parts of the Bible were on display. It was a fascinating exhibit depicting the tension developing in Europe between different religious factions. Outside in the square were rides and food
This church is probably one of the best attractions in Basel. I recommend all the visitors to go there and check it. The view on the back is really cool, you see a big part of Basel and the Rhin.

Our most recent visit was as the Christmas Market was being organized but not fully ready for guests.. there were food stands and the setting is perfect for such a market. We enjoyed being there in spite of the chilly wind.

This cathedral is made of red sandstone and colourful roof tiles which is both striking and beautiful as the architecture and colour makes it stand out from the surrounding buildings. Behind the cathedral is a nice view of the Rhine River, bridge and buildings on the opposite
Located in the very heart of this small and attractive Swiss city, the Church is very well maintained and certainly worth a visit, even if a short one
Great views of the Rhine and Christmas time the area has a Christmas market, not the biggest of cathedrals

text.wiki:
Basel ( BAH-zəl, German: [ˈbaːzl̩] (listen)) or Basle ( BAHL; French: Bâle [bɑl]; Italian: Basilea [baziˈlɛːa]; Romansh: Basilea [baziˈleːa] (listen)) is a city in northwestern Switzerland on the river Rhine. Basel is Switzerland's third-most-populous city (after Zürich and Geneva) with about 180,000 inhabitants. The official language of Basel is (the Swiss variety of Standard) German, but the main spoken language is the local Basel German dialect.
The city is known for its many museums, ranging from the Kunstmuseum, the first collection of art accessible to the public in Europe (1661) and the largest museum of art in Switzerland, to the Fondation Beyeler (located in Riehen). The University of Basel, Switzerland's oldest university (founded in 1460), and the city's centuries-long commitment to humanism, have made Basel a safe haven at times of political unrest in other parts of Europe for such notable people as Erasmus of Rotterdam, the Holbein family, Friedrich Nietzsche, and in the 20th century also Hermann Hesse and Karl Jaspers.
The city of Basel is Switzerland's second-largest economic centre after the city of Zürich and has the highest GDP per capita in the country, ahead of the cantons of Zug and Geneva. In terms of value, over 94% of Basel City's goods exports are in the chemical and pharmaceutical sectors. With production facilities located in the neighbouring Schweizerhalle, Basel accounts for 20% of Swiss exports and generates one-third of the national product.Basel has been the seat of a Prince-Bishopric since the 11th century, and joined the Swiss Confederacy in 1501. The city has been a commercial hub and an important cultural centre since the Renaissance, and has emerged as a centre for the chemical and pharmaceutical industries in the 20th century. In 1897, Basel was chosen by Theodor Herzl as the location for the first World Zionist Congress, and altogether the congress has been held there ten times over a time span of 50 years, more than in any other location. The city is also home to the world headquarters of the Bank for International Settlements. The name of the city is internationally known through institutions like the Basel Accords, Art Basel and FC Basel.
In 2019 Basel, was ranked among the ten most liveable cities in the world by Mercer together with Zürich and Geneva.


== History ==


=== Early history ===

There are traces of a settlement at the nearby Rhine knee from the early La Tène period (5th century BC). In the 2nd century BC, there was a village of the Raurici at the site of Basel-Gasfabrik(to the northwest of the Old City, and likely identical with the town of Arialbinnum that was mentioned on the Tabula Peutingeriana). The unfortified settlement was abandoned in the 1st century BC in favour of an oppidum on the site of Basel Minster, probably in reaction to the Roman invasion of Gaul.
In Roman Gaul, Augusta Raurica was established some 20 km (12 mi) from Basel as the regional administrative centre, while a castra (fortified camp) was built on the site of the Celtic oppidum. The city of Basel eventually grew around the castra. In AD 83, Basel was incorporated into the Roman province of Germania Superior. Roman control over the area deteriorated in the 3rd century, and Basel became an outpost of the Provincia Maxima Sequanorum formed by Diocletian.
The Germanic confederation of the Alemanni attempted to cross the Rhine several times in the 4th century, but were repelled; one such event was the Battle of Solicinium (368). However, in the great invasion of AD 406, the Alemanni appear to have crossed the Rhine river a final time, conquering and then settling what is today Alsace and a large part of the Swiss Plateau. From that time, Basel has been an Alemannic settlement.
The Duchy of Alemannia fell under Frankish rule in the 6th century, and by the 7th century, the former bishopric of Augusta Raurica was re-established as the Bishopric of Basel. Based on the evidence of a third solidus with the inscription Basilia fit, Basel seems to have minted its own coins in the 7th century. Under bishop Haito, the first cathedral was built on the site of the Roman castle, later replaced by a Romanesque structure consecrated in 1019. At the partition of the Carolingian Empire, Basel was first given to West Francia, but it passed to East Francia with the treaty of Meerssen of 870.
The city was plundered and destroyed by a Magyar invasion in 917. The rebuilt city became part of Upper Burgundy, and as such was incorporated into the Holy Roman Empire in 1032.


=== Prince-Bishopric of Basel ===

From the donation by Rudolph III of Burgundy of the Moutier-Grandval Abbey and all its possessions to Bishop Adalbero II of Metz in 999 until the Reformation, Basel was ruled by Prince-Bishops (see Bishop of Basel, whose memory is preserved in the crosier shown on the Basel coat of arms – see above).
In 1019, the construction of the cathedral of Basel (known locally as the Münster) began under Henry II, Holy Roman Emperor. In 1225–1226, a bridge, now known as the Middle Bridge, was constructed by Bishop Heinrich von Thun and Lesser Basel (Kleinbasel) founded as a bridgehead to protect the bridge. The bridge was largely funded by Basel's Jewish community who had settled there a century earlier. For many centuries to come Basel possessed the only permanent bridge over the river "between Lake Constance and the sea".
The Bishop also allowed the furriers to establish a guild in 1226. Eventually about 15 guilds were established in the 13th century. They increased the town's, and hence the bishop's, reputation, influence, and income from the taxes and duties on goods in Basel's expanding market. The Crusade of 1267 set out from Basel.
The plague came to Europe in 1347, but did not reach Basel until June 1349. The guilds, asserting that the Jews were responsible—several had been tortured and confessed—demanded they be executed, which the Council did in January 1349, except for a few who escaped to Alsace. During the Basel massacre, 600 Jews were murdered. They were shackled inside a wooden barn on an island in the Rhine, which was set afire. The few survivors – young orphans – were forcibly converted to Christianity. The council then forbade Jews in Basel for 200 years, except that their money was helpful in rebuilding after the Basel earthquake of 1356 which destroyed much of the city along with a number of castles in the vicinity. The city offered courts to nobles as an alternative to rebuilding their castles, in exchange for the nobles' military protection of the city.

In 1412 (or earlier), the well-known Gasthof zum Goldenen Sternen was established. Basel became the focal point of western Christendom during the 15th century Council of Basel (1431–1449), including the 1439 election of antipope Felix V. In 1459, Pope Pius II endowed the University of Basel, where such notables as Erasmus of Rotterdam and Paracelsus later taught. At the same time the new craft of printing was introduced to Basel by apprentices of Johann Gutenberg.
The Schwabe publishing house was founded in 1488 by Johannes Petri and is the oldest publishing house still in business. Johann Froben also operated his printing house in Basel and was notable for publishing works by Erasmus. In 1495, Basel was incorporated into the Upper Rhenish Imperial Circle; the Bishop of Basel was added to the Bench of the Ecclesiastical Princes of the Imperial Diet. In 1500 the construction of the Basel Münster was finished. In 1521 so was the bishop. The Council, under the supremacy of the guilds, explained that henceforth they would only give allegiance to the Swiss Confederation, to whom the bishop appealed but in vain.


=== As a member state in the Swiss Confederacy ===

The city had remained neutral through the Swabian War of 1499 despite being plundered by soldiers on both sides. The Treaty of Basel ended the war and granted the Swiss confederates exemptions from the emperor Maximillian's taxes and jurisdictions, separating Switzerland de facto from the Holy Roman Empire.On 9 June 1501, Basel joined the Swiss Confederation as its eleventh canton. It was the only canton that was asked to join, not the other way round. Basel had a strategic location, good relations with Strasbourg and Mulhouse, and control of the corn imports from Alsace, whereas the Swiss lands were becoming overpopulated and had few resources. A provision of the Charter accepting Basel required that in conflicts among the other cantons it was to stay neutral and offer its services for mediation.In 1503, the new bishop Christoph von Utenheim refused to give Basel a new constitution; whereupon, to show its power, the city began to build a new city hall.In 1529, the city became Protestant under Oecolampadius and the bishop's seat was moved to Porrentruy. The bishop's crook was however retained as the city's coat of arms. For centuries to come, a handful of wealthy families collectively referred to as the "Daig" played a pivotal role in city affairs as they gradually established themselves as a de facto city aristocracy.
The first edition of Christianae religionis institutio (Institutes of the Christian Religion – John Calvin's great exposition of Calvinist doctrine) was published at Basel in March 1536.In 1544, Johann von Brugge, a rich Dutch Protestant refugee, was given citizenship and lived respectably until his death in 1556, then buried with honors. His body was exhumed and burnt at the stake in 1559 after it was discovered that he was the Anabaptist David Joris.In 1543, De humani corporis fabrica, the first book on human anatomy, was published and printed in Basel by Andreas Vesalius (1514–1564).There are indications Joachim Meyer, author of the influential 16th-century martial arts text Kunst des Fechten ("The Art of Fencing"), came from Basel. In 1662 the Amerbaschsches Kabinett was established in Basel as the first public museum of art. Its collection became the core of the later Basel Museum of Art.
The Bernoulli family, which included important 17th- and 18th-century mathematicians such as Jakob Bernoulli, Johann Bernoulli and Daniel Bernoulli, were from Basel. The 18th-century mathematician Leonhard Euler was born in Basel and studied under Johann Bernoulli.


=== Modern history ===
In 1792, the Republic of Rauracia, a revolutionary French client republic, was created. It lasted until 1793. After three years of political agitation and a short civil war in 1833 the disadvantaged countryside seceded from the Canton of Basel, forming the half canton of Basel-Landschaft.On 3 July 1874, Switzerland's first zoo, the Zoo Basel, opened its doors in the south of the city towards Binningen.

In 1897 the first World Zionist Congress was held in Basel. Altogether the World Zionist Congress was held in Basel ten times, more than in any other city in the world.On 16 November 1938, the psychedelic drug LSD was first synthesized by Swiss chemist Albert Hofmann at Sandoz Laboratories in Basel.
In 1967, the population of Basel voted in favor of buying three works of art by painter Pablo Picasso which were at risk of being be sold and taken out of the local museum of art, due to a financial crisis on the part of the owner's family. Therefore, Basel became the first city in the world where the population of a political community democratically decided to acquire works of art for a public institution. Pablo Picasso was so moved by the gesture that he subsequently gifted the city with an additional three paintings.


=== Basel as a historical, international meeting place ===
Basel has often been the site of peace negotiations and other international meetings. The Treaty of Basel (1499) ended the Swabian War. Two years later Basel joined the Swiss Confederation. The Peace of Basel in 1795 between the French Republic and Prussia and Spain ended the First Coalition against France during the French Revolutionary Wars. In more recent times, the World Zionist Organization held its first congress in Basel from 29 August through 31 August 1897. Because of the Balkan Wars, the (Socialist) Second International held an extraordinary congress at Basel in 1912. In 1989, the Basel Convention was opened for signature with the aim of preventing the export of hazardous waste from wealthy to developing nations for disposal.


== Name ==

The origin of the name of Basel is uncertain. It may be derived from the Roman-era toponym Basilia, which originally meant a public building and later a church. Another theory is that it comes through the from the personal Greek name Basilius. The Old French form Basle was adopted into English, and developed into the modern French Bâle. The Icelandic name Buslaraborg goes back to the 12th century Leiðarvísir og borgarskipan chronicle.


== Geography and climate ==


=== Location ===
Located where the Swiss, French and German borders meet, Basel also has suburbs in France and Germany. As of 2016, the Swiss Basel agglomeration was the third-largest in Switzerland, with a population of 541,000 in 74 municipalities in Switzerland (municipal count as of 2018). The initiative Trinational Eurodistrict Basel (TEB) of 62 suburban communes including municipalities in neighboring countries, counted 829,000 inhabitants in 2007. Basel is the most densely populated city in Switzerland.


=== Topography ===

Basel has an area, as of 2009, of 23.91 square kilometers (9.23 sq mi). Of this area, 0.95 km2 (0.37 sq mi) or 4.0% is used for agricultural purposes, while 0.88 km2 (0.34 sq mi) or 3.7% is forested. Of the rest of the land, 20.67 km2 (7.98 sq mi) or 86.4% is settled (buildings or roads), 1.45 km2 (0.56 sq mi) or 6.1% is either rivers or lakes.Of the built up area, industrial buildings made up 10.2% of the total area while housing and buildings made up 40.7% and transportation infrastructure made up 24.0%. Power and water infrastructure as well as other special developed areas made up 2.7% of the area while parks, green belts and sports fields made up 8.9%. Out of the forested land, all of the forested land area is covered with heavy forests. Of the agricultural land, 2.5% is used for growing crops and 1.3% is pastures. All the water in the municipality is flowing water.


=== Climate ===
Under the Köppen system, Basel features a continental-influenced oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb), due to its relatively far inland position. The city averages 120.4 days of rain or snow annually and on average receives 842 mm (33.1 in) of precipitation. The wettest month is May during which time Basel receives an average of 99 mm (3.9 in) of rain. The month with the most days of precipitation is also May, with an average of 12.4 days. The driest month of the year is February with an average of 45 mm (1.8 in) of precipitation over 8.4 days.


== Politics ==
The city of Basel functions as the capital of the Swiss half-canton of Basel-Stadt, though several of its suburbs are located in the half-canton of Basel-Landschaft or the canton of Aargau. Others are even located in France and Germany.


=== Canton ===
The canton Basel-Stadt consists of three municipalities: Riehen, Bettingen, and the city Basel itself. The political structure and agencies of the city and the canton are identical.


=== City ===


==== Quarters ====
The city itself has 19 quarters:

Grossbasel (Greater Basel):
Kleinbasel (Lesser Basel):


=== Coat of arms ===
The blazon of the municipal coat of arms is In Silber ein schwarzer Baselstab. (Argent, a staff of Basel sable)
(For "staff", see Heraldsnet website.)


=== Government ===
The canton's executive, the Executive Council (Regierungsrat), consists of seven members for a mandate period of 4 years. They are elected by any inhabitant valid to vote on the same day as the parliament, but by means of a system of Majorz, and operates as a collegiate authority. The president (German: Regierungspräsident(in)) is elected as such by a public election, while the heads of the other departments are appointed by the collegiate. The current president is Dr Guy Morin. The executive body holds its meetings in the red Town Hall (German: Rathaus) on the central Marktplatz. The building was built in 1504–14.
As of 2016, Basel's Executive Council is made up of three representatives of the SP (Social Democratic Party), and one member each of Green Alliance of Basel (GB) (who is the president), FDP (Free Democratic Party), LDP (Liberal-Demokratische Partei of Basel), and CVP (Christian Democratic Party), giving the left parties a combined four out of seven seats. The last election was held on 23 October and 27 November 2016.

Barbara Schüpbach-Guggenbühlis is State Chronicler (Staatsschreiberin) since 2009, and Marco Greiner is Head of Communication (Regierungssprecher) and Vice State Chronicler (Vizestaatsschreiber) since 2007 for the Executive Council.


=== Parliament ===

The parliament, the Grand Council of Basel-Stadt (Grosser Rat), consists of 100 seats, with members (called in German: Grossrat/Grossrätin) elected every 4 years. The sessions of the Grand Council are public. Unlike the members of the Executive Council, the members of the Grand Council are not politicians by profession, but they are paid a fee based on their attendance. Any resident of Basel allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the parliament. The delegates are elected by means of a system of Proporz, and political parties must have surpassed an election quorum of 4% per election district to enter the council, but this will end with the next election in 2020. The legislative body holds its meetings in the red Town Hall (Rathaus).
The last election was held on 23 October 2016 for the mandate period (Legislatur) of 2017–2021. As of 1 February 2017, the Grand Council consist of 35 members of the Social Democratic Party (SP), 15 members of the Swiss People's Party (SVP), 13 Grünes Bündnis (GB) (a collaboration of the Green Party (GPS), its junior party, and Basels starke Alternative (BastA!)), 15 Liberal-Demokratische Partei (LDP) and its junior party, 10 The Liberals (FDP) and its junior party, the representative of the Aktive Bettingen (AB) is associated to the parliamentary group (Fraktion) of the FDP, 8 (7/1) Christian Democratic People's Party (CVP)/Evangelical People's Party (EVP), and 3 Green Liberal Party (GLP).The left parties missed an absolute majority by two seats.


=== Federal elections ===


==== National Council ====
In the 2019 federal election the most popular party was the Social Democratic Party (SP) which received two seats with 34% (−1) of the votes. The next five most popular parties were the Green Party (GPS) (19.4%, +7.3), the LPS (14.5%, +3.6) and the FDP (5.8, −3.5), which are chained together at 20.3%, (+0.1), the SVP (11.3%, ), and the Green Liberal Party (GLP) (5%, +0.6), CVP (4.1%, -1.9). In the federal election, a total of 44,628 votes were cast, and the voter turnout was 49.4%.On 18 October 2015, in the federal election the most popular party was the Social Democratic Party (SP) which received two seats with 35% of the votes. The next three most popular parties were the FDP (20.2%), the SVP (16.8%), and the Green Party (GPS) (12.2%), each with one seat. In the federal election, a total of 57,304 votes were cast, and the voter turnout was 50.4%.


==== Council of States ====
On 20 October 2019, in the federal election Eva Herzog, member of the Social Democratic Party      (SP), was elected for the first time as a State Councillor (Ständerätin) in the first round as single representative of the canton of Basel-Town and successor of Anita Fetz in the national Council of States (Ständerat) with an absolute majority of 37'210 votes.On 18 October 2015, in the federal election State Councillor (German: Ständerätin) Anita Fetz, member of the Social Democratic Party       (SP), was re-elected in the first round as single representative of the canton of Basel-Town in the national Council of States (Ständerat) with an absolute majority of 35'842 votes. She has been a member of it since 2003.


=== International relations ===


==== Twin towns and sister cities ====
Basel has two sister cities and a twinning among two states:
 Shanghai, China, since 2007
 US State Massachusetts, since 2002
 Miami Beach, US, since 2011


==== Partner cities ====
 Rotterdam, Netherlands, since 1945


== Demographics ==


=== Population ===
Basel has a population (as of August 2019) of 177,654.  As of 2015, 35.5% of the population are resident foreign nationals. Over the last 10 years (1999–2009 ) the population has changed at a rate of −0.3%. It has changed at a rate of 3.2% due to migration and at a rate of −3% due to births and deaths.Of the population in the municipality 58,560 or about 35.2% were born in Basel and lived there in 2000. There were 1,396 or 0.8% who were born in the same canton, while 44,874 or 26.9% were born somewhere else in Switzerland, and 53,774 or 32.3% were born outside of Switzerland.In 2008 there were 898 live births to Swiss citizens and 621 births to non-Swiss citizens, and in same time span there were 1,732 deaths of Swiss citizens and 175 non-Swiss citizen deaths.  Ignoring immigration and emigration, the population of Swiss citizens decreased by 834 while the foreign population increased by 446.  There were 207 Swiss men and 271 Swiss women who emigrated from Switzerland.  At the same time, there were 1756 non-Swiss men and 1655 non-Swiss women who immigrated from another country to Switzerland.  The total Swiss population change in 2008 (from all sources, including moves across municipal borders) was an increase of 278 and the non-Swiss population increased by 1138 people.  This represents a population growth rate of 0.9%.As of 2000, there were 70,502 people who were single and never married in the municipality.  There were 70,517 married individuals, 12,435 widows or widowers and 13,104 individuals who are divorced.As of 2000 the average number of residents per living room was 0.59 which is about equal to the cantonal average of 0.58 per room. In this case, a room is defined as space of a housing unit of at least 4 m2 (43 sq ft) as normal bedrooms, dining rooms, living rooms, kitchens and habitable cellars and attics. About 10.5% of the total households were owner occupied, or in other words did not pay rent (though they may have a mortgage or a rent-to-own agreement).
As of 2000, there were 86,371 private households in the municipality, and an average of 1.8 persons per household. There were 44,469 households that consist of only one person and 2,842 households with five or more people.  Out of a total of 88,646 households that answered this question, 50.2% were households made up of just one person and there were 451 adults who lived with their parents.  Of the rest of the households, there are 20,472 married couples without children, 14,554 married couples with children There were 4,318 single parents with a child or children.  There were 2,107 households that were made up of unrelated people and 2,275 households that were made up of some sort of institution or another collective housing.In 2000 there were 5,747 single family homes (or 30.8% of the total) out of a total of 18,631 inhabited buildings.  There were 7,642 multi-family buildings (41.0%), along with 4,093 multi-purpose buildings that were mostly used for housing (22.0%) and 1,149 other use buildings (commercial or industrial) that also had some housing (6.2%).  Of the single family homes 1090 were built before 1919, while 65 were built between 1990 and 2000.  The greatest number of single family homes (3,474) were built between 1919 and 1945.In 2000 there were 96,640 apartments in the municipality.  The most common apartment size was 3 rooms of which there were 35,958.  There were 11,957 single room apartments and 9,702 apartments with five or more rooms.  Of these apartments, a total of 84,675 apartments (87.6% of the total) were permanently occupied, while 7,916 apartments (8.2%) were seasonally occupied and 4,049 apartments (4.2%) were empty.  As of 2009, the construction rate of new housing units was 2.6 new units per 1000 residents.As of 2003 the average price to rent an average apartment in Basel was 1118.60 Swiss francs (CHF) per month (US$890, £500, €720 approx. exchange rate from 2003).  The average rate for a one-room apartment was 602.27 CHF (US$480, £270, €390), a two-room apartment was about 846.52 CHF (US$680, £380, €540), a three-room apartment was about 1054.14 CHF (US$840, £470, €670) and a six or more room apartment cost an average of 2185.24 CHF (US$1750, £980, €1400).  The average apartment price in Basel was 100.2% of the national average of 1116 CHF. The vacancy rate for the municipality, in 2010, was 0.74%.


==== Historical population ====


=== Language ===
Most of the population (as of 2000) speaks German (129,592 or 77.8%), with Italian being second most common (9,049 or 5.4%) and French being third (4,280 or 2.6%). There are 202 persons who speak Romansh.


=== Religion ===

From the 2000 census, 41,916 or 25.2% were Roman Catholic, while 39,180 or 23.5% belonged to the Swiss Reformed Church. Of the rest of the population, there were 4,567 members of an Orthodox church (or about 2.74% of the population), there were 459 individuals (or about 0.28% of the population) who belonged to the Christian Catholic Church, and there were 3,464 individuals (or about 2.08% of the population) who belonged to another Christian church. There were 12,368 individuals (or about 7.43% of the population) who were Muslim. There were 1,325 individuals (or about 0.80% of the population) who were Jewish, however only members of religious institutions are counted as such by the municipality, which makes the actual number of people of Jewish descent living in Basel considerably higher. There were 746 individuals who were Buddhist, 947 individuals who were Hindu and 485 individuals who belonged to another church. 52,321 (or about 31.41% of the population) belonged to no church, are agnostic or atheist, and 8,780 individuals (or about 5.27% of the population) did not answer the question.


== Infrastructure ==


=== Quarters ===
Basel is subdivided into 19 quarters (Quartiere). The municipalities of Riehen and Bettingen, outside the city limits of Basel, are included in the canton of Basel-Stadt as rural quarters (Landquartiere).


=== Transport ===
Basel's airport is set up for airfreight; heavy goods reach the city and the heart of continental Europe from the North Sea by ship along the Rhine. The main European routes for the highway and railway transport of freight cross in Basel. The outstanding location benefits logistics corporations, which operate globally from Basel. Trading firms are traditionally well represented in the Basel Region.


==== Port ====

Basel has Switzerland's only cargo port, through which goods pass along the navigable stretches of the Rhine and connect to ocean-going ships at the port of Rotterdam.


==== Air transport ====
EuroAirport Basel Mulhouse Freiburg is operated jointly by two countries, France and Switzerland, although the airport is located completely on French soil. The airport itself is split into two architecturally independent sectors, one half serving the French side and the other half serving the Swiss side; prior to Schengen there was an immigration inspection point at the middle of the airport so that people could "emigrate" to the other side of the airport.


==== Railways ====

Basel has long held an important place as a rail hub. Three railway stations—those of the German, French and Swiss networks—lie within the city (although the Swiss (Basel SBB) and French (Bâle SNCF) stations are actually in the same complex, separated by Customs and Immigration facilities). Basel Badischer Bahnhof is on the opposite side of the city. Basel's local rail services are supplied by the Basel Regional S-Bahn. The largest goods railway complex of the country is located just outside the city, spanning the municipalities of Muttenz and Pratteln. The new highspeed ICE railway line from Karlsruhe to Basel was completed in 2008 while phase I of the TGV Rhin-Rhône line, opened in December 2011, has reduced travel time from Basel to Paris to about 3 hours.


==== Roads ====
Basel is located on the A3 motorway.
Within the city limits, five bridges connect Greater and Lesser Basel (downstream):

Schwarzwaldbrücke (built 1972)
Wettsteinbrücke (current structure built 1998, original bridge built 1879)
Mittlere Rheinbrücke (current structure built 1905, original bridge built 1225 as the first bridge to cross the Rhine River)
Johanniterbrücke (built 1967)
Dreirosenbrücke (built 2004, original bridge built 1935)


==== Ferries ====
A somewhat anachronistic yet still widely used system of reaction ferry boats links the two shores. There are four ferries, each situated approximately midway between two bridges. Each is attached by a cable to a block that rides along another cable spanning the river at a height of 20 to 30 metres (66 to 98 feet). To cross the river, the ferryman orients the boat around 45° from the current so that the current pushes the boat across the river. This form of transportation is therefore completely hydraulically driven, requiring no outside energy source.
[1]


==== Public transport ====

Basel has an extensive public transportation network serving the city and connecting to surrounding suburbs, including a large tram network. The green-colored local trams and buses are operated by the Basler Verkehrs-Betriebe (BVB). The yellow-colored buses and trams are operated by the Baselland Transport (BLT), and connect areas in the nearby half-canton of Baselland to central Basel. The BVB also shares commuter bus lines in cooperation with transit authorities in the neighboring Alsace region in France and Baden region in Germany. The Basel Regional S-Bahn, the commuter rail network connecting to suburbs surrounding the city, is jointly operated by SBB, SNCF and DB.


==== Border crossings ====
Basel is located at the meeting point of France, Germany and Switzerland; because it is so near other countries and is beyond the Jura Mountains, many within the Swiss military reportedly believe that the city is indefensible during wartime. It has numerous road and rail crossings between Switzerland and the other two countries. With Switzerland joining the Schengen Area on 12 December 2008, immigration checks were no longer carried out at the crossings. However, Switzerland did not join the European Union Customs Union (though it did join the EU Single Market) and customs checks are still conducted at or near the crossings.

France-Switzerland (from east to west) 

Road crossings (with French road name continuation)
Kohlenstrasse (Avenue de Bâle, Huningue). This crossing replaces the former crossing Hüningerstrasse further east.
Elsässerstrasse (Avenue de Bâle, Saint-Louis)
Autobahn A3 (A35 autoroute, Saint-Louis)
EuroAirport Basel-Mulhouse-Freiburg – pedestrian walkway between the French and Swiss sections on Level 3 (departures) of airport.
Burgfelderstrasse (Rue du 1er Mars, Saint Louis)
Railway crossing
Basel SBB railway stationGermany-Switzerland (clockwise, from north to south)

Road crossings (with German road name continuation)
Hiltalingerstrasse (Zollstraße, Weil am Rhein). Tram 8 goes along this road to Weil am Rhein. The extension opened in 2014; it used to end before the border.
Autobahn A2 (Autobahn A5, Weil am Rhein)
Freiburgerstrasse (Baslerstraße, Weil am Rhein)
Weilstrasse, Riehen (Haupstraße, Weil am Rhein)
Lörracherstrasse, Riehen (Baslerstraße, Stetten, Lörrach)
Inzlingerstrasse, Riehen (Riehenstraße, Inzlingen)
Grenzacherstrasse (Hörnle, Grenzach-Wyhlen)
Railway crossing
Between Basel SBB and Basel Badischer Bahnhof – Basel Badischer Bahnhof, and all other railway property and stations on the right bank of the Rhine belong to DB and are classed as German customs territory. Immigration and customs checks are conducted at the platform exit tunnel for passengers leaving trains here.Additionally there are many footpaths and cycle tracks crossing the border between Basel and Germany.


=== Health ===

As the biggest town in the Northwest of Switzerland numerous public and private health centres are located in Basel. Among others the Universitätsspital Basel and the Universitätskinderspital Basel. The anthroposophical health institute Klinik-Arlesheim (formerly known as Lukas-Klinik and Ita-Wegman-Klinik) are both located in the Basel area as well. Private health centres include the Bethesda Spital and the Merian Iselin Klinik. Additionally the Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute is located in Basel too.


=== Energy ===
Basel is at the forefront of a national vision to more than halve energy use in Switzerland by 2050. To research, develop and commercialise the technologies and techniques required for the country to become a 2000 Watt society, a number of projects have been set up since 2001 in the Basel metropolitan area. These include demonstration buildings constructed to Minergie or Passivhaus standards, electricity generation from renewable energy sources, and vehicles using natural gas, hydrogen and biogas.
A building construction law was passed in 2002 also which stated that all new flat roofs must be greened leading to Basel becoming the world's leading green roof city. This was driven by an energy saving programme.A hot dry rock geothermal energy project was cancelled in 2009 since it caused induced seismicity in Basel.


== Economy ==

The city of Basel, located in the heart of the tri-border region (called Dreiländereck) is one of the most dynamic economic regions of Switzerland.
As of 2016, Basel had an unemployment rate of 3.7%. As of 2008, there were 18 people employed in the primary economic sector and about 9 businesses involved in this sector. 34,645 people were employed in the secondary sector and there were 1,176 businesses in this sector. 120,130 people were employed in the tertiary sector, with 8,908 businesses in this sector. There were 82,449 residents of the municipality who were employed in some capacity, of which females made up 46.2% of the workforce.
In 2008 the total number of full-time equivalent jobs was 130,988. The number of jobs in the primary sector was 13, of which 10 were in agriculture and 4 were in forestry or lumber production. The number of jobs in the secondary sector was 33,171 of which 24,848 or (74.9%) were in manufacturing, 10 were in mining and 7,313 (22.0%) were in construction. The number of jobs in the tertiary sector was 97,804. In the tertiary sector; 12,880 or 13.2% were in wholesale or retail sales or the repair of motor vehicles, 11,959 or 12.2% were in the movement and storage of goods, 6,120 or 6.3% were in a hotel or restaurant, 4,186 or 4.3% were in the information industry, 10,752 or 11.0% were the insurance or financial industry, 13,695 or 14.0% were technical professionals or scientists, 6,983 or 7.1% were in education and 16,060 or 16.4% were in health care.In 2000, there were 121,842 workers who commuted into the municipality and 19,263 workers who commuted away. The municipality is a net importer of workers, with about 6.3 workers entering the municipality for every one leaving. About 23.9% of the workforce coming into Basel are coming from outside Switzerland, while 1.0% of the locals commute out of Switzerland for work. Of the working population, 49.2% used public transportation to get to work, and 18.7% used a private car.

The Roche Tower, designed by Herzog & de Meuron, is 41 floors and 178 metres (584 ft) high, upon its opening in 2015 it has become the tallest building in Switzerland. Basel has also Switzerland's third tallest building (Basler Messeturm, 105 m (344 ft)) and Switzerland's tallest tower (St. Chrischona TV tower, 250 m (820 ft)).


=== Chemical industry ===
The Swiss chemical industry operates largely from Basel, and Basel also has a large pharmaceutical industry. Novartis, Syngenta, Ciba Specialty Chemicals, Clariant, Hoffmann-La Roche, Basilea Pharmaceutica and Actelion are headquartered there. Pharmaceuticals and specialty chemicals have become the modern focus of the city's industrial production.


=== Banking ===
Banking is important to Basel:

UBS AG maintains central offices in Basel,
The Bank for International Settlements is located within the city and is the central banker's bank. The bank is controlled by a board of directors, which is composed of the elite central bankers of 11 different countries (US, UK, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Switzerland, the Netherlands and Sweden).According to the BIS, "The choice of Switzerland for the seat of the BIS was a compromise by those countries that established the BIS: Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States. When consensus could not be reached on locating the Bank in London, Brussels or Amsterdam, the choice fell on Switzerland. An independent, neutral country, Switzerland offered the BIS less exposure to undue influence from any of the major powers. Within Switzerland, Basel was chosen largely because of its location, with excellent railway connections in all directions, especially important at a time when most international travel was by train."
Created in May 1930, the BIS is owned by its member central banks, which are private entities. No agent of the Swiss public authorities may enter the premises without the express consent of the bank. The bank exercises supervision and police power over its premises. The bank enjoys immunity from criminal and administrative jurisdiction, as well as setting recommendations which become standard for the world's commercial banking system.Basel is also the location of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, which is distinct from the BIS. It usually meets at the BIS premises in Basel. Responsible for the Basel Accords (Basel I, Basel II and Basel III), this organization fundamentally changed Risk management within its industry.
Basel also hosts the headquarters of the Global Infrastructure Basel Foundation, which is active in the field of sustainable infrastructure (financing).
